newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan PM aims to stay on in new coalition alliance.
newsitem.headline: Japan PM aims to stay on in new coalition alliance.

text.p: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said on Monday that Japan's election results showed his party had not fully regained public confidence, but he pledged to stay at the helm in a new coalition.
"I would like to continue to be in charge of the government as the leader of the party which has the largest number of seats in parliament," Hashimoto told a news conference.

Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) captured 239 seats in the 500-seat Lower House of parliament, just short of a simple majority that would have put the LDP back in one-party government after three years of coalition rule.

Hashimoto was due to meet the leaders of the other parties in the outgoing three-way coalition, Sakigake's Shoichi Ide and Takako Doi of the Social Democrats, later on Monday to try to form a new working majority.
Hashimoto said he was not ruling out links with any other politicians who could join forces with his LDP.

"The important thing is to stress what is common between us and other politicians, either as individuals or in a group, to work together," Hashimoto said in a reply to a question about whether he would make an overture to the fledgling Democratic Party, which won 52 seats in the new Lower House.
In order to hold comfortable majorities in both houses of parliament, Hashimoto needs the Lower House seats held by the Democrats and the Upper House seats of the Social Democrats.
LDP officials have said they may also court independents and possible defectors from the main opposition Shinshinto (New Frontier Party).

Hashimoto said he favoured a continued coalition with the Social Democrats and Sakigake, even though both parties saw a sharp fall in support. The Social Democrats now hold 15 seats in the Lower House against 30 previously, while Sakigake has just two, compared with nine.

Asked how he regarded the overall results in Sunday's general elections, Hashimoto said: "The result means that we have not regained the full confidence of the people. It means that we have not been given a full score in our three-year effort to reform ourselves and that we must try even harder."
After a series of funding scandals, the LDP was toppled from power in 1993 after almost 38 years of single party government.
